choices.text: Aqueous layer is secreted by goblet cells
Aqueous layer is secreted by glands of Manz
Aqueous layer is secreted by lacrimal glands and glands of Krause & Wolfring
Aqueous layer is secreted by meibomian glands

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tear film secretion is correct?
questions.solution:
The conjunctival surface is lubricated by the tear film, which is a triple layered sandwich consisting of the following:

  1. Innermost mucinous layer lining the conjunctival cells and corneal epithelium secreted by the goblet cells, crypts of Henle, which are infoldings of conjunctiva, and glands of Manz, which are located in a ring around the margin of the cornea.
  2. Middle aqueous layer secreted by the lacrimal and accessory conjunctival glands of Krausefound along the inferior and superiors fornices of the conjunctival sac and Wolfring or Ciaccio, which are small tubular glands located near the upper tarsal border in the upper eyelid.
  3. Outermost superficial lipid layer secreted by the meibomian glands, which are vertically orientedsebaceous glands found within the tarsal plate and open along the eyelid margins, and limits the evaporation of tears.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 356

questions.text: A 76 year old lady complains of a headache for 2 days in the right side of the head. The pain is worse when she is chewing or talking. She has also had mild fevers and sweats. Her ESR is 80 mm/hr. The vision in the right eye is 6/18 and her left eye is 6/6. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
There are early signs of visual loss so high dose steroids should be commenced with the suspicion of temporal arteritis. Although all the other options are reasonable, they may take time and there should not be delay in commencing steroids.

questions.text: You are called to see a full-term newborn who is found to have abdominal distension with delayed passage of stool at 28 hours after birth. The pregnancy was remarkable for diet-controlled gestational diabetes and echogenic bowel on the second trimester ultrasonography. The newborn has been breastfeeding well with good urine output and no passage of stool. Examination reveals an alert, active newborn with a markedly distended, firm abdomen, and an externally patent rectum. In the course of the subsequent evaluation, a barium enema is performed. The following, the test that is MOST likely to reveal the underlying cause of this newborn's clinical and radiographic findings is a
questions.solution:
• Thisinfant's barium enema demonstrates meconium mixed with air in the right lower abdomen, a finding highly suggestive of meconium ileus, which most often occurs in infants with cystic fibrosis. Fifteen percent of newborns with cystic fibrosis have meconium ileus.
  • Intestinalobstruction should be suspected in a newborn with delayed passage of stools, abdominal distension, and vomiting.
  • A newborn suspected of having an intestinal obstruction should be evaluated by a pediatric surgeon, because the physical examination and plain abdominal radiographymay not distinguish an emergent condition such as midgut volvulus from a condition responsive to conservative care.

Reference: Nelson Essentials of Pediatrics, 1st South Asian edition, page number 2105

questions.text: Which among the following is not the landmark commonly used for location of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
LOCATION OF THE FACIAL NERVE TRUNK

The main methods of facial nerve trunk localisation can be divided into antegrade and retrograde. The former utilises anatomical landmarks to identify the nerve trunk after its exit from the stylomastoid foramen, which is then traced distally. Landmarks commonly used are: 1 the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. This is termed Conley's pointer (tragal pointer) and indicates the position of the facial nerve, which lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip;

  • theupper border of the posterior belly of the digastric Identification of this muscle not only helps to mobilise the parotid gland, but also exposes an area immediately superior, in which the facial nerve is usually located;
  • thesquamotympanic fissure;
  • thestyloid process (the nerve is superficial to it);
  • themastoid process can be drilled and the nerve identified more

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 790

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein values be the highest?
questions.solution:
Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels can be elevated in certain fetal abnormalities. In the context of the options provided:

Down's syndrome (a): Elevated MSAFP is not typically associated with Down's syndrome.

Omphalocele (b): Omphalocele can be associated with elevated MSAFP, but it is not usually as high as in gastroschisis.

Gastroschisis (c): Gastroschisis is a condition where the abdominal wall does not close properly, and abdominal contents herniate outside the body. MSAFP levels are often higher in gastroschisis compared to omphalocele.

Spina bifida occulta (d): Spina bifida occulta is not typically associated with significantly elevated MSAFP.

Therefore, among the given options, c. Gastroschisis is associated with the highest maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein values. Elevated MSAFP levels may prompt further investigation and monitoring to assess the possibility of fetal abnormalities.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th Edition - Page no 289, 290

  • Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile protein actinomycinthrough Under the influence of estrogens the muscles become more active and excitable and action potentials in the individual fibres become more frequent.
  • Theestrogen dominated uterus is also more sensitive to oxytocin.

Progesterone:

  • Promote secretory changes in the uterine endometrium during the later half of the monthlyfemale sexual cycle, thus prepares the uterus for implantation of the fertilized ovum.
  • Itaids estrogen in myometrial hypertrophy
  • Increasein the tortuosity of glands
  • lipidand glycogen deposits
  • Decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions, thereby helping to prevent expulsion of the implanted ovum but increases the amplitude of contraction.

Thermoactinomyces sacchari is a thermophilic actinomycete found predominantly in de- caying residual sugar cane fiber, called bagasse. Bagasse disease of the lungs, or bagassosis, is a pulmonary disorder brought about by the inhalation of dried bagasse dust.

questions.solution:

  • It isinteresting that the conjunctiva of the newborn is unable to produce follicles before 2 or 3 months of age so that an infection very early in life may appear initially as papillary conjunctivitis an develop into follicular conjunctivitis if it remains active for longer than 3 months.

questions.text: A 54 year old man has been progressively getting more confused. His symptoms began about three years ago when he noticed leg stiffness. At present his entire body feels stiff and he has a resting tremor in the limbs. His writing has become small. Over the last six months, he has developed hallucinations and reports seeing ghost figures, and is also becoming forgetful, on one occasion leaving the gas cooker on fire. On examination, his mini-mental score was 10/30. He has increased tone throughout which is spastic and cogwheeling. There is a tremor in all limbs. Cranial nerve examination reveals mild restriction of conjugate upgaze eye movement. His gait was shuffling with a tendency to fall backwards. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of progressive cognitive decline, fluctuating symptoms, visual hallucinations, extrapyramidal signs (rigidity and bradykinesia more prominent than tremor) suggest Lewy body dementia. It is progressive. Patients are at risk of falls and syncope.

Symptoms and signs of lewy body dementia probably result in part from disruption of information flow from the striatum to the neocortex, especially the frontal lobe.

The cause is multifactorial. Altered neuromodulator and/or neurotransmitter levels (eg, acetylcholine, dopamine) influence the function of many neuronal circuits.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page 3119

choices.text: Intracytoplasmic chlamydial bodies in epithelial cells and leukocytes
Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions
Gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the office with a genital ulcer. The ulcer is painless and appeared first as a papule. On examination of the genital, there is a single beefy-red ulcer on the glans penis without tenderness. The base has a granulation tissue. Which of the following is most likely present in the tissue smear sample of the ulcer?
questions.solution:
Granuloma inguinale is an ulcerative disease of male genitals. The disorder is characterized by painless genital ulcers without regional lymphadenopathy.

Histological evaluation is essential for the diagnosis of donovanosis. Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies.

First-line treatment for granuloma inguinale is azithromycin 1 g, followed by 500 mg daily. Intracytoplasmic chlamydial bodies in epithelial cells and leukocytes are seen in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions are seen in genital herpes Organisms in parallel strands are seen in chancroid.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 31, page 1076

questions.text: A patient with hip dislocation with limitation of abduction, flexion and internal rotation of hip. The limb appears shortened. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Since the question mentions limitation of abduction at hip there is adduction deformity of hip present plus flexion and internal rotation deformity and shortening present which is diagnostic of posterior dislocation of hip joint.

In case of anterior dislocation there will be flexion abduction and external rotation deformity present. There may be true lengthening, with the head palpable in the groin

questions.text: Jishan is 4 years old living with his grandmother attends a pediatric outpatient clinic with his grandmother who is concerned that he only seems to like to play with his toy train and insists on watching the same cartoon video every night before he goes to bed. He attends nursery where he plays with the toys but not with other children. His behaviour can be very difficult to manage at times. He does not say any words, whereas the grandmother's children were speaking in sentences at his age. On examination you notice he does not make eye contact with you and pushes his toy train back and forth on the floor. The rest of his examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Autismis a triad of impaired social interaction, speech and language disorder, and ritualistic and repetitive behaviour.
  • Children with Asperger syndrome have similar but less severe social impairments and near normal language development. (Option a)
  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder also presents with difficult behaviour but there is a triad of attention deficit, hyperactivity and impulsivity. (Option c)
  • Expressive language disorder-Here language alone is affected. (Option d)

questions.text: Which among the following is not a complication of parotid gland surgery?
questions.solution:
COMPLICATIONS OF PAROTID GLAND SURGERY

Complications of parotid gland surgery include:

  • haematoma formation;
  • infection;
  • deformity: unsightly scar and retromandibular hollowing;
  • temporary facial nerve weakness;
  • transection of the facial nerve and permanent facial weakness;
  • sialocele;
  • facial numbness;
  • permanent numbness of the ear lobe associated with great auricular nerve transection;
  • Frey's syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 792

questions.text: Upper two third of anterior vaginal wall prolapse leads to:
questions.solution:
A cystocele is a prolapse of the bladder into the anterior wall of the vagina. When the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall prolapses, it can result in a cystocele, which is a type of anterior compartment prolapse. This condition is often associated with a weakness or defect in the supportive structures of the pelvic floor.

The other options are described as follows:

b. Urethrocele: Prolapse of the urethra into the anterior wall of the vagina.

c. Enterocele: Prolapse of the small intestine into the rectovaginal space.

d. Lax perineum: Generalized weakening or laxity of the perineal tissues.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th Edition - Page no 451

questions.text: Identify the type of scotoma
questions.solution:
A Bjerrum scotoma is a type of visual field defect characterized by a specific pattern of visual field loss. It is associated with conditions like glaucoma, particularly in its early stages. The scotoma typically extends along the horizontal meridian in a crescent or arcuate shape.

Paracentral (A): This term generally refers to scotomas near the center of the visual field.

Seidel (B): Seidel scotoma is not a commonly recognized term in ophthalmology. It's possible that it might be a specific term used in a particular context.

Ring (D): A ring scotoma refers to a circular area of visual field loss.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 1024

questions.text: A 50 year old man has a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. He has had 2 episodes of collapses and a 24 hour ECG shows episodes of non sustained VT. Coronary angiography shows a 99% LAD artery stenosis and angioplasty was unsuccessful due to the tortuosity of the vessel. Echocardiography shows a dilated LV at 5.9cm with an ejection fraction of 30%. Which is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate therapy for a 50-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction, 2 episodes of collapses, and non-sustained VT on a 24-hour ECG is an implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 248, page 1756

questions.text: A patient suspected of IgA pemphigus is sent to you for histopathology. Histopathology is significant for neutrophilic infiltrate in the upper part of the epidermis. Indirect immunofluorescence detects circulating IgA autoantibodies in the patient's serum. This patient's underlying pathology is characterized by autoantibodies directed against which of the following cadherins?
questions.solution:
The SPD subtype of IgA pemphigus was shown to produce IgA autoantibodies against desmoglein 1, a desmosomal cadherin responsible for maintaining proper adhesion in cell junctions.

Neutrophilic infiltration of the upper epidermis characterizes the subcorneal pustular dermatosis subtype of IgA pemphigus.

In contrast, the intraepidermal neutrophilic dermatosis shows autoantibodies against desmoglein members of the cadherin superfamily, primarily in the lower epidermis.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 50, page 1738

questions.text: Above image shows
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Vitamin A Deficiency

  1. XN (night blindness). It is the earliest symptom of xerophthalmia in It has to be elicited by taking detailed history from the guardian or relative.
  2. X1A (conjunctival xerosis). It consists of one or more patches of dry, lustreless, nonwettable conjunctiva, which has been well described as 'emerging like sand banks at receding tide' when the child ceases to cry. These patches almost always involve the interpalpebralarea of the temporal quadrants and often the nasal quadrants as In more advanced cases, the entire bulbar conjunctiva may be affected. Typical xerosis may be associated with conjunctival thickening, wrinkling and pigmentation.
  3. X1B(Bitot's spots). It is an extension of the xerotic process seen in stage The Bitot's spot is a raised, silvery white, foamy, triangular patch of keratinised epithelium, situated on the bulbar conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area. It is usually bilateral and temporal, and less frequently nasal.
  4. X2 (corneal xerosis). The earliest change in the cornea is punctate keratopathy which beginsin the lower nasal quadrant, followed by haziness and/or granular pebbly Involved cornea lacks lustre.
  5. X3Aand X3B (corneal ulceration/keratomalacia), Stromal defects occur in the late stage due to colliquative necrosis and take several forms. Small ulcers (1-3 mm) occur peripherally; they are characteristically circular, with steep margins and are sharply demarcated. Large ulcers and areas of necrosis may extend centrally or involve the entire cornea. If appropriate therapy is instituted immediately, stromal defects involving less than one-third of corneal surface (X3A) usually heal, leaving some useful However, larger stromal defects (X3B) commonly result in blindness.
  6. XS (corneal scars). Healing of stromal defects results in corneal scars of different densitiesand sizes which may or may not cover the pupillary A detailed history is required to ascertain the cause of corneal opacity.
  7. XFC(Xerophthalmic fundus). It is characterized by typical seed-like, raised, whitish lesions scattered uniformly over the part of the fundus at the level of the optic disc.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 433

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs may be used in the treatment of long QT syndrome?
questions.solution:
Beta blockers are the mainstay of treatment in long QT syndrome. The most commonly used drugs are propranolol and nadolol but metoprolol and atenolol are also used. Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillators are the most effective treatment in high risk cases. The other drugs may produce a prolongation of the QT interval exacerbating risk of polymorphic VT and Torsades de pointes. For a list of drugs see QTdrugs.org. For an example of long QT syndrome.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 244, page 1760

choices.text: Loss of sensation over tip of little finger

questions.text: Deformity shown in the above image can cause?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the picture above is cubitus valgus. It is a late complication of non union of lateral condylar fracture of the humerus. Diminished growth at the lateral side of distal humerus epiphysis results in a cubitus valgus deformity

It results in a late-onset ulnar palsy also called as tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Therefore, anesthesia at the tip of the little finger, which is the zone of autonomous supply of ulnar nerve, is a feature.

The opposition of thumb is by opponens pollicis, innervated by a recurrent branch of the median nerve and not affected in cubitus valgus deformity.

TREATMENT:- At the earliest opportunity, the nerve should be transposed anteriorly from behind the medial epicondyle to prevent friction (anterior transposition of ulnar nerve).

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no: 104.

questions.text: What is the score for predicting pulmonary embolism according to modified wells score for a patient with heart rate > 100 bpm, hemoptysis and immobilisation of more than 3 days?
questions.solution:
The modified Wells score is used for assessing the pretest probability of pulmonary embolism (PE). The criteria and associated scores are as follows:

  • Clinical signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) (3 points)
  • An alternative diagnosis is less likely than a pulmonary embolism (3 points)
  • Heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute (1.5 points)
  • Immobilization for more than three days or surgery in the previous four weeks (1.5 points)
  • Hemoptysis(1 point)
  • Malignancy(1 point)

In the given scenario, with a heart rate > 100 bpm, hemoptysis, and immobilization of more than 3 days, the score would be 1.5 (heart rate) + 1 (hemoptysis) + 1.5 (immobilization) = 4 points.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 989

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy frequently wets his bed with foul-smelling urine. His parents are concerned and would like to know what they can do to prevent this. After obtaining a complete history and physical examination, which were both unremarkable, which of the following is an appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
• The evaluation of nocturnal enuresis requires a thorough history, a complete physical examination, and urinalysis.
  • Urinalysis is the most important screening test in a child with If the findings of the physical examination and urinalysis are negative and the history does not suggest a secondary cause of nocturnal enuresis, no further work-up is needed.

Reference: Nelson Essentials of Pediatrics, 1st South Asian edition, page number 2528

choices.text: Also known as recurrent periductal mastitis
Condition of recurrent retromammary infections and abscess
Smoking is being implicated as the risk factor
Treated by antibiotics and incision and drainage

questions.text: Which among the following condition is not true for zuska's disease?
questions.solution:
Zuska's disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. This syndrome is managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary. Attempts to obtain durable long-term control by wide debridement of chronically infected tissue and/or terminal duct resection have been reported and can be curative, but they can also be frustrated by postoperative infections.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 550

questions.text: A researcher is calculating the child survival indices for different populations. Which of the following should he use for calculating the same?
questions.solution:
• Under-5mortality rate is used for calculating the child survival indices.
  • It is calculated as (1000-under 5 mortality rate)/ 10

Reference: Park's textbook of Preventive and Social medicine, 25th edition, pg 630

questions.text: Lesion involving Meyer's loop causes:
questions.solution:
The fibers from the optic tract relay into the lateral geniculate body and then continue into the optic radiation. Hence, lesions involving the optic radiation also result in Homonymous Hemianopia.

However the fibers responsible for the superior visual field course initially into the temporal lobe before proceeding posteriorly to reach the occipital lobe (Meyer's Loop). Hence, lesions involving the temporal lobe produce contralateral homonymous field defects involving only the superior field. This is known as Superior Quadrantanopia or Pie in the Sky.

The fibers responsible for the inferior visual field course through the parietal lobe and subsequently to the occipital lobe. Hence lesions of the parietal lobe result in contralateral homonymous field defect involving only the inferior field. This is known as Inferior Quadrantanopia or Pie on the Floor.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 910

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with breathlessness that has been getting gradually worse over a few weeks and she has difficulty mobilising. On physical examination she is found to have a large left sided pleural effusion. The presence of the effusion is confirmed by chest radiography. The most appropriate initial investigation would be:
questions.solution:
The first investigation should be diagnostic aspiration of pleural fluid.

Light's criteria can be used to distinguish transudates from exudates: in exudates at least one of the following three criteria are met:

pleural fluid protein concentration greater than 50% of that in plasma; pleural fluid LDH greater than 60% of that in plasma;

pleural fluid LDH more that two thirds the upper limit of normal in plasma

In general, if the protein is < 3 g then it is considered to be a transudate, if > 3 g then it is an exudate.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Pg:2006-2008

questions.text: A 14-year-old female has recently been diagnosed with sarcoidosis. You are evaluating her in your clinic for complaints that her shortness of breath is more frequent and severe. At this point in disease progression. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
• Childhood sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease of unknown etiology that causes noncaseating granuloma formation.
  • It is rare in children, but when it does affect those in the pediatric population, they usually are between 13 to 15 years old at age of onset.
  • There is no gender predilection for childhood sarcoidosis.
  • The lungs are the most frequently involved organ in sarcoidosis, although the disease has the potential to affect any organ system.
  • Lymph nodes, eyes, skin, liver, and spleen are other organs often involved in childhood sarcoidosis.
  • Oral glucocorticoid therapy, such as with oral prednisone, is the mainstay of treatment of pulmonary sarcoidosis.

Reference: Nelson Essentials of Pediatrics, 1st South Asian edition, page number 2077

questions.text: Which immunosuppressive agent acts by preventing lymphocyte proliferation?
questions.solution:
Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive agent that inhibits lymphocyte proliferation. It is commonly used in transplant medicine and autoimmune diseases to prevent the rejection of transplanted organs and to control autoimmune responses.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1538

questions.text: Differentiating features of psoriatic arthritis from RA is?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic arthritis:-

Presentation is like rheumatoid arthritis - a polyarthritis, distal IP joints of hands involved (unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these are spared)

RA factor is negative. Male and Females are equally affected.

There is a strong genetic predisposition; family history of psoriasis is often present and almost 60% patients who have a concomitant sacroiliitis or spondylitis lesion are positive for HLA-B27.

HLA-Cw6 gene is also associated with the disorder. Classic skin lesions and nail lesion help in diagnosis

The patient may presents with one of several pattern of joint involvement.(described by

Wright and Mall)

  1. arthritis of DIP joints
  2. asymmetrical oligoarthritis :Most common pattern
  3. symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA
  4. axial involvement with similar to ankylosing spondylitis
  5. arthritis mutilans

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition - Page no:991

questions.text: A 51 year old patient with rheumatoid arthritis has the following full blood count results: Hemoglobin 10.5 g/dL, Platelets 450 x 10⁹/L, White Cell Count 8.5 x 10⁹/L, MCV 103 fL. Which drug is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Tetrahydrofolate is necessary for the synthesis of the nucleotides of both DNA and RNA. Methotrexate-polyglutamate inhibits the de novo purine synthesis of both purine and thymidylate synthase, thereby inhibiting DNA synthesis. Methotrexate may lead to macrocytosis as a result of B12 or folate deficiency. It may also be associated with bone marrow suppression, causing leucopenia or thombocytoenia. Methotrexate may also cause mouth ulcers, stomatitis, cough and dyspnoea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an epithelial/sub-epithelial corneal dystrophy?

Prominent examples in this group of epithelial/sub-epithelial corneal dystrophies are:

Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD, map-dot-fingerprint dystrophy, Cogan microcystic epithelial dystrophy, anterior basement membrane dystrophy), Meesmann corneal dystrophy (MECD, juvenile hereditary epithelial dystrophy) and gelatinous drop-like corneal dystrophy (GDLD, subepithelial amyloidosis, primary familial amyloidosis [Grayson]).

Fuch's is an example of Endothelial corneal dystrophy.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumour arises from kulchitsky cells
Carcinoid tumour most commonly occurs in appendix
Most common site is middle part of appendix
It rarely give rise to metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for carcinoid tumour of appendix?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumour (synonym: argentaffinoma):

Carcinoid tumours arise in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn) and are most common in the vermiform appendix. Carcinoid tumour is found once in every 300-400 appendices subjected to histological examination. In many instances, the appendix had been removed because of symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis. The tumour can occur in any part of the appendix, but it is frequently found in the distal third. The neoplasm feels moderately hard and, on sectioning the appendix, it can be seen as a yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and the peritoneum. Microscopically, the tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle and have a characteristic pattern using immune histochemical stain for chromogranin B. Unlike carcinoid tumours arising in other parts of the intestinal tract, carcinoid tumour of the appendix rarely gives rise to metastases.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1315

questions.text: All are De Lancey's level 1 support except
questions.solution:
DeLancey's three-level system of support classifies the pelvic floor into three levels based on the support structures. Level 1 support represents the most superior level of support. In this context:

  1. Mackenrodt's or Cardinal ligament: Also known as the cardinal ligament, it is a part of level 1 support.
  2. Uterosacral ligament: This ligament is also part of level 1 support.
  3. Perineal muscle: The perineal muscles are not considered part of DeLancey's level 1 support. The perineal body, which is a fibromuscular structure, is part of level 3 support.

In summary, the correct answer is c. Perineal muscle because it is not part of DeLancey's level 1 support.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th Edition - Page no 449

questions.text: A 27 year old man presents with sudden onset left sided pleuritic chest pain and breathlessness. On examination he is distressed, tachypnoeic and has tracheal displacement to the right together with a hyper-resonant percussion note on the left side. There were no breath sounds on the left. Chest x ray shows a < 2 cm left sided pneumothorax. What is the best management procedure?
questions.solution:
Treatment of a pneumothorax of < 2 cm margin would be initial aspiration.

This is less painful, leads to a shorter duration of admission, reduces the need for pleurectomy.

questions.text: Miami criteria is for
questions.solution:
The Miami criteria are used for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) assay during parathyroidectomy. This criterion helps determine the success of parathyroid surgery by assessing the drop in PTH levels following the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: In which of the following transition meiosis occurs?
questions.solution:
The process involved in the development of spermatids from the primordial male germ cells and their differentiation into spermatozoa (or sperms) is called as spermatogenesis.

  1. Spermatogenesis begins at puberty in seminiferous tubules of male testes.

Cell divisions are of two kinds:

  1. In mitosis, the chromosome number remains the same.
  2. Meiosis is a special type of cell division that reduces the diploid number of chromosomes(i.e., 46) to the haploid number of It takes place only in germ cells; to give rise to gametes (sperms and egg cells) It involves two meiotic cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.

The first metotic division is a reduction division because the chromosome number is reduced from diploid (46) to haploid (23).

The 2nd meiotic division is similar to mitosis as daughter cells formed contain the same haploid number of chromosomes as the mother cell.

Thus, though option 'a' and 'b' both are correct but reduction division occurs when primary spermatocyte is transformed to secondary spermatocyte, so it is the answer of choice.

  • The developmental process from spermatogonium to sperm takes about 72-74 days and the entire process, including the transit time in the ductal system takes approximately three months.
  • Clinical significance : The above fact is clinically significant, as in case of male factor infertility a repeat semen analysis to see the sperm count, motility etc. after giving treatment should be done three months after the first analysis (as new sperms will be formed after 3 months).
  • Spermsattain maturity and motility in epididymis.
  • A mature sperm is 55 micrometers (50-60 µm).

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th Edition - Page no 19

questions.text: A 34 year old woman has generalized joint pains and muscle aches. She also complains of gritty sensations in the eye in the mornings. Blood tests show Anti Nuclear Antibody ++, Rheumatoid Factor ++. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dry mouth, dry eyes, fatigue, muscle aches and joint pains are typical of Sjogren's syndrome. 80% of patients are ANA positive and 75% are Rheumatoid factor positive. A useful diagnostic test is the Schirmer's test, where a piece of filter paper is placed in the corner of the eye to measure the degree of wetting after five minutes.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to your office for evaluation of left lower eyelid ecchymosis. There is 3mm proptosis of the left eye. Her medical history is significant for treatment of some unknown tumor. Which of the following childhood tumors is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Proptosis in a child indicates an orbital process that may have infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic causes. This patient has only eyelid ecchymosis and no signs of orbital inflammation. Retinoblastoma presents as an intraocular tumor with the potential for orbital spread. Even though this tumor can present with orbital involvement, the commonest presentation is Leukocoria.

Neuroblastoma often presents with proptosis, globe displacement, and eyelid ecchymosis. In the majority of cases, these orbital tumors represent metastasis from the primary abdominal tumor. These patients have increased urine levels of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA). Treatment of this metastatic orbital disease is a combination of radiation and chemotherapy.

Leukemia can lead to orbital involvement with proptosis. The most frequent form of leukemia to affect the orbit is acute myelogenous leukemia (chloroma).

Eyelid ecchymosis is not a common finding in orbital involvement with leukemia or rhabdomyosarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is another tumor that should be suspected in any child with progressive proptosis.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 111-112

questions.text: A 51 year old man has developed unsteadiness. He has hypertension and is a smoker of 20 cigarettes per day. On examination he has cerebellar ataxia and past pointing. His CXR shows a right hilar mass. Which of the following is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a paraneoplastic syndrome. Anti Yo antibodies are found in around half of all patients with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Associated with small cell carcinoma, ovarian tumours and Hodgkin's lymphoma. Anti Hu antibodies are associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung. It is usually associated with sensory neuropathy or with encephalomyelitis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Chapter 438, pages 668, 672, and 3216.

questions.text: A 37 year old patient with HIV is assessed for new onset right arm weakness. An MRI scan of his head shows a temporoparietal ring enhancing lesion. Which is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by a single-celled parasite called Toxoplasma gondii. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of a ring enhancing lesion causing neurological defect in a HIV patient. In immunosuppressed patients, especially patients with AIDS, the parasite can reactivate and cause disease, usually when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/microL

questions.text: Which among the following is the hamartomatous polyp of the large intestine?
questions.solution:
A juvenile polyp is a type of hamartomatous polyp found in the large intestine. Hamartomatous polyps are non-neoplastic growths that result from disorganized overgrowth of normal tissues. Juvenile polyps are commonly seen in children and are typically solitary, sessile or pedunculated, and have a smooth surface. They are most often found in the rectum and sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Amsel's criteria of bacterial vaginosis includes all except
questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to alteration of vaginal flora; lactobacilli decrease whereas coccobacilli and Gardnerella increase.

It is the most common vaginitis.

Amsel's criteria includes:

  • White milky, non viscous, adherent vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH more than 4.5
  • Positive whiff test: amine odour with 10% KOH
  • Presence of clue cells
  • Increase in number of gardenerella vaginalis and reduced number of lactobacilli

Treatment: tab. Metronidazole 2 g single dose or tinidazole or clindamycin 300 mg BD for 7 days

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents with palpitations and heat intolerance. On examination her pulse is 90/min and a small, diffuse goitre is noted which is tender to touch. Thyroid function tests show the following:

Free T₄ 24 pmol/L
TSH < 0.05 mIU/L

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis with tender goitre = subacute (De Quervain's) thyroiditis

Whilst Grave's disease is the most common cause of thyrotoxicosis it would not cause a tender goitre. In the context of thyrotoxicosis this finding is only really seen in De Quervain's thyroiditis. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder of the thyroid gland. It is typically associated with hypothyroidism although there may be a transient thyrotoxicosis in the acute phase. The goitre is a non-tender in Hashimoto's.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:377 Pg:2708-9

questions.text: Which among the following conditions is not associated with hyperthyroidism in thyroid storm?
questions.solution:
Thyroid Storm Thyroid storm is a condition of hyperthyroidism accompanied by fever, central nervous system agitation or depression, and cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure. The condition may be precipitated by abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications, infection, thyroid or nonthyroid surgery, and trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis. Occasionally, thyroid storm may result from amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents or following RAI therapy. This condition was previously associated with high mortality rates but can be appropriately managed in an intensive care unit setting. β-Blockers are given to reduce peripheral T4 to T3 conversion and decrease the hyperthyroid symptoms. Oxygen supplementation and hemodynamic support should be instituted. Nonaspirin compounds can be used to treat pyrexia, and Lugol's iodine or sodium ipodate (intravenously) should be administered to decrease iodine uptake and thyroid hormone secretion. PTU therapy blocks the formation of new thyroid hormone and reduces peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Corticosteroids often are helpful to prevent adrenal exhaustion and block hepatic thyroid hormone conversion.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1638

questions.text: Deep transverse arrest of head is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Deep transverse arrest is a complication of occipitoposterior position,so cannot occur in transverse lie.

Causes of deep transverse arrest:

  • Faulty pelvic architecture - Android pelvis
  • Depresion of the head
  • Weak uterine contractions
  • Laxity of pelvic floor muscles:

- Epidural analgesia causes prolonged 2nd stage of labour. In transverse lie; presenting part is shoulder; so DTA of head cannot occur.

questions.text: Which among the following variables is not included in the estimation of breast cancer according to gail model?
questions.solution:
Age at menopause - This variable is not explicitly included in the Gail Model. The variables included in the model typically focus on age, reproductive history, and certain breast-related factors. Age at menopause is not directly factored into the Gail Model.

The other variables mentioned, such as history of benign disease, age at first live birth, and specific age categories, are part of the Gail Model for breast cancer risk estimation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with hypertension that his MD doctor is finding difficult to manage. There are a number of metabolic abnormalities and he is concerned about the possibility of Conn's syndrome. The blood picture is one of metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and low renin and aldosterone levels. What diagnosis fits with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Gordon's syndrome presents as almost the mirror image of the metabolic abnormalities seen in Bartter's syndrome, and is caused primarily by renal sodium retention and volume expansion.

Addison's disease is, of course, associated with hypotension and hyperkalaemia.

Conn's syndrome is primary hyperaldosteronism and is associated with hypokalaemia. In general, the emergency treatment of hyperkalaemia is well documented, with acute administration of calcium to reduce the risk of arrhythmias, insulin to drive potassium into cells and the use of ion-exchange resins to increase the excretion of potassium via the gastrointestinal tract.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Pg:2094, 309, 1899

questions.text:
A 65 year old lady has investigations for renal impairment (creatinine 2.4 mg/dl). She has a previous history of hypertension, peripheral vascular disease and osteoarthritis. She has been taking diclofenac for 6 years and penicillamine for the past 2 years (the drug was stopped 1 year ago).

Urine : protein +, blood -ve
Ultrasound of kidneys : right 7.8 cm, left 8 cm in length.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ischemic nephropathy is kidney disease caused by a lack of adequate blood flow. The likely diagnosis is renovascular disease due to the small kidney size.

There is only 1+ Proteinuria. The other clue is the history of hypertension. The normal length of kidneys is between 10-13 cm.

questions.text: Which among the following is not the management parameter useful in the initial 4 hours in a patient of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
In the initial 4 hours of managing acute pancreatitis, the focus is primarily on assessing the severity of the condition and providing appropriate supportive care. CT scan is not typically performed within the first few hours and is usually reserved for later stages of management when the initial assessment and stabilization have been completed.

Ranson's severity scoring, fluid resuscitation, and SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome) score are crucial parameters in the initial management of acute pancreatitis to assess the severity of the condition, guide fluid resuscitation, and monitor for signs of systemic inflammation.

Complicated Cataract

This name is given to cataracts arising due to inflammatory or degenerative diseases of the eye. It is usually the posterior subcapsular cataract. It has a typical bread crumb appearance with polychromatic lustre. The causes are

questions.text:
A 38 year old lady has noticed mild jaundice, worsening joint pains and is complaining of itching on her skin for the past 8 months. On examination, she has palpable hepatomegaly and a bronze pigmentation on her skin. Her liver function tests show a bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL, ALT 100 U/L, ALP 480 U/L. ANA is negative, anti-mitochondrial antibody is positive at 1/320.

Which of the following medications is helpful?
questions.solution:
Primary biliary cirrhosis is described. Liver transplantation does not cure the condition. Histology shows white cell damage to the biliary epithelium with non necrotising granuloma formation in the portal triad.

Ursodeoxycholic acid lowers serum bilirubin and symptoms of itching, and prolongs the progression towards requirement for liver transplantation. IgM levels are particularly high in PBC.

questions.text: What is the characteristic histological lesion in crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Microscopic features. Mucosal and submucosal edema may be noted microscopically before any gross changes. A chronic inflammatory infiltrate appears in the mucosa and submucosa and extends transmurally. This inflammatory reaction is characterized by extensive edema, hyperemia, lymphangiectasia, intense infiltration of mononuclear cells, and lymphoid hyperplasia. Characteristic histologic lesions of Crohn disease are noncaseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells. Granulomas appear later in the course and are found in the wall of the bowel or in regional lymph nodes in 60% to 70% of patients.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1261

questions.text: All of the folowing are known causes of recurrent abortion except:
questions.solution:
TORCH infections do not lead to recurrent abortion.

SLE is an established cause for recurrent abortion. SLE is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (anti-cardiolipin antibodies) and is known to cause recurrent abortions. RH incompatibility is a known cause for spontaneous abortion and may lead to recurrent abortions if it remains unrecognized. Syphilis also does not lead to recurrent abortions but to rule out one option between TORCH infection and syphilis, it isTORCH infection.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 7th edition - Page no 68

questions.text:
A 15 year girl presents with a non-blanching rash over his shins and a swollen knee. She has noticed haematuria. Blood tests show a urea of 72 mg/dl and Creatinine 3 mg/dl. Urine dipstick shows: blood +++, protein +.

What is the renal biopsy likely to show ?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation fits Henoch Schönlein purpura. This is an autoimmune disorder (cause unknown but associated with mycoplasma), which is related to multisystemic IgA deposition. It is usually a self-limited disease. It is the most common form of childhood vasculitis and results in inflammatory changes in small vessels. The symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura usually begin suddenly and may include headache, fever, loss of appetite, cramping abdominal pain, and joint pain. Red or purple spots typically appear on the skin (petechial purpura). Inflammatory changes associated with Henoch-Schönlein Purpura can also develop in the joints, kidneys, digestive system, and, in rare cases, the brain and spinal cord. Mesangial Ig A deposits are typical features of HSP on the renal biopsy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Principles, 20th edition, ch:356 pg:2586

questions.text: A 30 year old female with history of headache is sent for fundus examination.On examination she is found to have generalised arterial attenuation with multiple cotton wool spots and flame shaped hemorrhages in both eyes.The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Retinopathy:

The primary response of the retinal arterioles to systemic hypertension is vasoconstriction; this is less marked in older individuals due to involutional sclerosis conferring increased rigidity. Arteriolosclerosis refers to hardening and loss of elasticity of small vessel walls, manifested most obviously by arteriovenous (AV) nipping (nicking) at crossing points; its presence makes it probable that hypertension has been present for many years, even if the BP is currently controlled. Mild AV changes may be seen in the absence of hypertension. In sustained hypertension the inner blood–retinal barrier is disrupted, increased vascular permeability leading to flame-shaped retinal haemorrhages and oedema.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page number 557

questions.text:
A 19 year old woman is referred to the GP by her teacher. The teacher was concerned about frequent episodes of day dreaming during class and poor examination results over the past year.
Which one of the Following needs to be excluded?
questions.solution:
Daydreaming in children can be easily confused with absence or complex partial seizures, in which staring is a prominent and common feature. However, lip smacking, eye blinking, or stiffening of muscle groups is common during seizures but not during daydreaming.

questions.text: What is the grade of the peripheral arterial disease for severe claudication according to Rutherford classification?
questions.solution:
In the Rutherford classification of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), severe claudication is categorized as Grade III. The Rutherford classification is commonly used to classify the severity of PAD based on clinical presentation and hemodynamic parameters.

The Rutherford classification for PAD is as follows:

  • Grade 0: Asymptomatic
  • Grade I: Mild claudication
  • Grade II: Moderate claudication
  • Grade III: Severe claudication
  • Grade IV: Rest pain
  • Grade V: Ischemic ulceration not exceeding ulcer of the digits of the foot
  • Grade VI: Severe ischemic ulcers or frank gangrene

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 954

questions.text: Most sensitive test for the diagnosis of enteric fever?
questions.solution:
The definitive diagnosis of enteric fever requires the isolation of S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi from blood, bone marrow, other sterile sites, rose spots, stool, or intestinal secretions. The sensitivity of blood culture is only 40-80%, probably because of high rates of antibiotic use in endemic areas and the small number of Typhi organisms (i.e., <15/mL) typically present in the blood. Because almost all S. Typhi organisms in blood are associated with the mononuclear cell/platelet fraction, centrifugation of blood and culture of the buffy coat can substantially reduce the time to isolation of the organism but do not increase sensitivity. Bone marrow culture is >80% sensitive, and, unlike that of blood culture, its yield is not reduced by up to 5 days of prior antibiotic therapy. Culture of intestinal secretions (best obtained by a noninvasive duodenal string test) can be positive despite a negative bone marrow culture. If blood, bone marrow, and intestinal secretions are all cultured, the yield is >90%. Stool cultures, although negative in 60-70% of cases during the first week, can become positive during the third week of infection in untreated patients

Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition. Page no: 1176

questions.text: A 44 year old man has a diagnosis of Ulcerative Colitis. He was incidentally found to have positive anti smooth muscle antibodies by the GP who sent an autoimmune screen. Which is the next recommended test for this patient?

choices.text: A ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter, probably due to atresia of the ureteric orifice
The classic sign of a ureterocoele on ultrasound is of a 'cobra head'
On cystoscopy, a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice is typical which fills with and empties of urine with ureteric peristalsis

questions.text: Which is false regarding ureterocele?
questions.solution:
• A ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter, probably due to atresia of the ureteric orifice.
  • Ureterocoeles affect females more often than males (4:1) and 10% are bilateral.
  • The condition occurs almost exclusively in Caucasians.
  • Similar to ectopic ureters, ureters with ureterocoeles frequently drain the upper pole and are often associated with dysplastic or non-functional renal tissue.
  • In childhood, they usually present with infection.
  • When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice.
  • In adults, ureterocoeles typically present with stones in the lower ureter.
  • Ultrasound will demonstrate a cystic, well-defined, rounded mass in the posterior bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1401

choices.text: Immediate clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which is not included in active management of 3rd stage of Labor?
questions.solution:
Active management of the third stage of labour includes:

  1. Administration of a uterotonic soon after birth (best is oxytocin followed by misoprost
  2. Delayed cord damping
  3. Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction
  4. Uterine massage.

'Early cord clamping' should not be included in active management of labour. The reason why early cord clamping is being discouraged is because if cord is clamped immediately the cord blood present in it(80-100 ml) will go waste whereas, if delayed cord clamping is done, the cord blood goes to the newborn and their are less chances of anemia, intraventricular hemorrhage and late onset sepsis especially in preterm infants.

questions.text:
A 21 year old man presents with a collapse whilst running for the bus. He has no known past medical history. An ECG done on admission to the hospital fulfils the criteria for LVH. On examination, he has a jerky pulse and prominent apex beat. There is a systolic murmur heard in the aortic area.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy which is familial, can present with presyncopal episodes as described above. Over a hundred different mutations in at least nine different genes, all encoding sarcomeric polypeptides, have been associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). LVH changes with strain pattern and prominent q waves are common on the ECG. A prominent, jerky pulse is a clue.

questions.text: A 20-year-young female presented for antenatal checkup. She was in 1st trimester and was diagnosed to have an ovarian cyst. Treatment of choice:

• Patient is presenting in the first trimester with ovarian cyst

  • Surgery in the first trimester is best avoided, as during surgery a corpus luteal cyst or ovary might be removed which will be detrimental to the pregnancy, which may end up in a miscarriage.
  • Therefore, all such cases should be operated (ovariotomy/cystectomy) in the second trimester.
  • Therefore, the best time of elective operation for an ovarian tumor in pregnancy is between 14 to 18 weeks, as the chances of abortion are less and access to the pedicle is easy.

questions.text: Which among the following is not the haematological cause of indication of splenectomy?
questions.solution:
TIPS has replaced the operative shunt technique in the management of acute variceal bleeding. TIPS is a radiological intervention that involves the creation of a shunt between the portal and hepatic veins to decompress the portal system, reducing the risk of variceal bleeding. It is a less invasive alternative to surgical shunts.

Other options:

a)Balloon tamponade: Balloon tamponade (e.g., with a Sengstaken-Blakemore tube) can be a temporary measure to control acute variceal bleeding, but it is not a definitive treatment and is often used as a bridge to more definitive therapies.

b)Pharmacotherapy: Pharmacotherapy, including medications like vasoactive agents (e.g., octreotide) and antibiotics, is commonly used in the acute management of variceal bleeding, but it is not a shunting procedure.

d)Variceal banding: Variceal banding is a procedure used for the prevention of recurrent variceal bleeding. It involves placing rubber bands around esophageal varices during endoscopy to induce variceal eradication.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 28th Edition - Page no 1185

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong with regard to vitamins?
questions.solution:
Option A: Deficiency of a single vitamin of the B complex is rare since poor diets are most often associated with multiple deficiency states.

Option B: Vitamins are a group of organic nutrients, required in small quantities for a variety of biochemical functions that,

Option C: generally, cannot be synthesised by the body and must therefore be supplied in the diet.

Option D: Vitamins are a diverse group of chemical molecules; all are chemically not amine in nature. But the term vitamin, however, is continued without the final letter 'e'. So the term vitamine (vital amine) is considered a misnomer.

questions.text: Which of the following plants is commonly referred to as poison hemlock?
questions.solution:
Conium maculatum is commonly referred to as poison hemlock. Poison hemlock refers to the plant Conium maculatum. This plant is highly toxic and contains various alkaloids, including coniine and gamma-coniceine, which can be deadly if ingested.

Ricinus communis (A): This is the castor oil plant. While the seeds of this plant contain ricin, a toxic protein, it is not commonly referred to as poison hemlock.

Abrus precatorius (B): This plant is known as the rosary pea or jequirity pea. It contains the toxic compound abrin. However, it is not commonly referred to as poison hemlock.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for fever, malaise, and skin rash. He appears pale. His temperature is 102 F, pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows non-tender, erythematous macule on the palms as shown below. On auscultation, early diastolic murmur, loudest at the left sternal border is heard. Blood cultures grow gram-positive, catalase- positive cocci that express mecA. Intravenous antibiotic therapy is begun with an agent that disrupts cell membranes by creating transmembrane channels. Which of the following adverse events is associated with the use of this agent?
questions.solution:
Vancomycin binds terminal D-ala-D-ala of cell-wall precursor peptides →inhibition of cell wall synthesis (peptidoglycan formation) → bacterial death (bactericidal effect against most gram-positive bacteria)

Red man syndrome, an anaphylactoid reaction caused by rapid infusion of vancomycin. Caused by nonspecific mast cell degranulation → rapid release of histamine. Symptoms include diffuse flushing of the skin, pruritus mainly of the upper body, Muscle spasms and pain in the back and chest, Possible hypotension and dyspnea. Red man syndrome can be prevented by slowing the rate of infusion and pretreating with antihistamines

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Pg no. 809

questions.text: The tumour suppressor gene p53 induces cell cycle at which phase?
questions.solution:
The tumor suppressor gene that is most commonly affected by point mutations in cancer is TP53, a prototypical 'guardian' type tumor suppressor gene. DNA damage leads to activation of p53 by phosphorylation. Activated p53 drives transcription of CDKN1A (p21), which prevents RB phosphorylation, thereby causing a G1-S block in the cell cycle. This pause allows the cells to repair DNA damage.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 212,213

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, chronic cough, shortness of breath, night sweats, hemoptysis and weight loss for 15 days. She was diagnosed with HIV 7 years ago. Her CD4 cell count is 50/cumm. Her chest xray is given below. The doctor suspects a MAC infection in the patient. According to the Runyon classification, which group does MAC belong to?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex (MAC) belongs to the group of Nonphotochromogens in the Runyon classification. This classification is based on the pigment production of the mycobacteria when exposed to light.

Runyon classification:

Photochromogens (A): These mycobacteria produce pigments when exposed to light. Example: M. kansasii.

Scotochromogens (B): These mycobacteria produce pigments in the dark but not when exposed to light. Example: M. scrofulaceum.

Nonphotochromogens (C): These mycobacteria do not produce pigments regardless of light exposure. Example: M. avium-intracellulare complex (MAC).

Rapid growers (D): These mycobacteria grow quickly on laboratory media. Example: M. fortuitum.

Reference: Apurva Shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no 636

questions.text: In which of the following fractures is the ossicular chain disrupted?
questions.solution:
Temporal bone fracture is usually a sequela of significant blunt head injury.

Longitudinal temporal bone fractures are petrous temporal bone fractures that occur parallel to the long axis of the petrous temporal bone. Ossicular injury including incudostapedial joint dislocation can occur resulting in conducting hearing loss.

Transverse temporal bone fractures are oriented perpendicular to the long axis of the petrous temporal bone, with the line of force running roughly anterior to posterior. Facial nerve injury can occur resulting in facial palsy.

Lateral flow of the sample will result in binding of antigen to specific monoclonal antibodies resulting in colour band formation. pLDH is an antigen present in all species of Plasmodia. It is not a species-specific antigen. Species specific antigen in P.falciparum is pHRP-2.

Option A,B & D - are examples of diagnosis of parasitic infection using their species specific antigen.

questions.text: BRCA-1 is more commonly associated with which type of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Carcinomas with medullary features are a special type of triple-negative cancer comprising about 5% of all breast cancers. These carcinomas typically grow as rounded masses. They consist of sheets of large anaplastic cells associated with pronounced lymphocytic infiltrates composed predominantly of T cells.The presence of lymphocytes is associated with a favorable prognosis, at least in part due to a better response to chemotherapy compared to poorly differentiated carcinomas without lymphoid infiltrates.This type of carcinoma is seen frequently in women with germline BRCA1 mutations, but most women with these carcinomas are not carriers.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 743-744

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male diagnosed with psychosis and violent behavior is admitted for management in a psychiatric care facility. Which of the following factors should be kept in mind while planning for Electroconvulsive therapy in this patient?
1) Prior response to Electroconvulsive therapy should be considered
2) Pre-anaesthetic workup is essential
3) Diabetes, even though well-controlled with oral hypoglycemics, is a contraindication for Electroconvulsive therapy procedure
4) Advanced age, more than 35 years, is a contraindication for this procedure
5) Brain imaging should compulsorily be done before an Electroconvulsive procedure
6) Informed consent of both patient and care-giver is essential
questions.solution:
While planning for Electroconvulsive therapy procedure, prior response to ECT should be considered. Pre-anaesthetic fitness is essential and informed consent of both patient and relative are essential. There are no absolute contraindications for ECT. Well controlled diabetes/ hypertension is not a contraindication for ECT. Also, brain imaging should be performed before ECT only if there is clinical suspicion of a brain pathology, and not as a routine procedure.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 1067.

questions.text: The highest value of Minimum Alveolar concentration is for which of the following Inhalational agents?
questions.solution:
The Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) is a measure of an inhalational anesthetic's potency. It represents the concentration of the anesthetic in the alveoli of the lungs that prevents movement in response to a noxious stimulus in 50% of patients.

In this case, the correct answer is Xenon.

Xenon has the highest Minimum Alveolar Concentration among the options provided. Xenon is an inert gas with anesthetic properties, and its MAC is higher compared to other inhalational agents like desflurane, enflurane, and isoflurane. It's worth noting that xenon is not commonly used as a primary anesthetic due to its cost and limited availability.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 188

Most trematodes except Schistosomes require two intermediate hosts for completion of life cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following can be aptly considered the definition of a 'Hamartoma'?
questions.solution:
Hamartoma is a mass of disorganized tissue indigenous to the particular site, such as the lung or the liver. While traditionally considered developmental malformations, many hamartomas have clonal chromosomal aberrations that are acquired through somatic mutations and on this basis are now considered to be neoplastic.
