questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with high fever, headache, myalgia, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Two weeks ago, he returned from Africa, where he was taking care of patients infected with filovirus. His mucous membranes appear dry. Laboratory studies show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum transaminases. A serum RTPCR reaction confirms infection with a filovirus. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of the causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
This man's presentation in addition to his recent history of taking care of patients infected with a filovirus in an African country suggests Ebola Virus Disease (EVD).

Ebola virus, a Filovirus is transmitted via direct contact with bodily fluids from infected patients, fomites, and infected nonhuman primates or fruit bats. After an incubation period of 3 weeks, affected individuals usually present with acute flu-like symptoms, vomiting, and diarrhoea (potentially severe enough to cause dehydration), as seen in this patient.

Additional manifestations of Ebola virus disease (EVD) include bradycardia and pulse- temperature dissociation. As EVD progresses, patients can present with diffuse hemorrhage, hypovolemic shock, multiorgan failure, and DIC. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment, and the mortality rate is usually high.

Reference: Apurva Shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no edition 665

choices.text: Tuberomammillary nucleus and Pre-optic nucleus of hypothalamus

questions.text: Which areas of the brain are involved in regulation of sleep and wakefulness?
questions.solution:
REGULATION OF SLEEP AND WAKEFULNESS:

  1. Arousal spectrum: Arousal spectrum is linked to the actions of five neurotransmitters, histamine, dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin and acetylcholine. These neurotransmitter circuits as a group are called the ascending reticular activating system, because they are known to work together to regulate arousal.
  2. Sleep/ Wake switch: There is another set of circuits in the hypothalamus that regulate sleep and wake discontinuously, called the sleep/wake switch. The 'on' switch is known as the wake promoter and is localized within the tuberomammillary nucleus (TMN) of the hypothalamus. The 'off' switch is known as the sleep promoter and is localized within the ventrolateral preoptic (VLPO) nucleus of the hypothalamus.
  3. Regulators of sleep/wake switch: Two other sets of neurons function as regulators of the sleep/wake switch: orexin containing neurons of the lateral hypothalamus (LAT) and melatonin-sensitive neurons of the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 269

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with an acute first psychotic episode was started on olanzapine 15 mg at night. After 10 days, she developed rigidity, pyrexia and autonomic instability. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The following are differential diagnoses of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS):

  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: according to the DSM-IV, NMS is characterised by muscle rigidity and an elevated temperature associated with the administration of an antipsychotic medication. Two or more symptoms of autonomic instability need to be present, and blood investigations should be instigated. There is an absence of infection, general medical condition or substance use that may result in a similar condition. It is estimated to occur in 0.2-1% of patients treated with dopamine-blocking agents. It is also known to occur in other neurological disorders (e.g. Wilson's disease, Parkinson's disease treated with dopamine-blocking agents). 210 Mock examination It may also occur in patients treated with dopamine antagonists given for nausea (e.g. metoclopramide, prochlorperazine).
  • Encephalitis: this may present with a viral prodrome, meningeal signs, other neurological signs, seizures, and imaging and cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities.
  • Acute dystonia: this is usually not associated with pyrexia and autonomic instability.
  • Malignant catatonia: idiopathic malignant catatonia is due to advanced stages of psychosis and may be difficult to differentiate from NMS, which is also thought to be an iatrogenic malignant catatonia.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 925

questions.text:
You are studying biochemical reactions of bacteria. You come across the following test wherein a suspension of the bacteria along with bile salts gives a string like formation. Which of the following biochemical reactions will this bacteria show?

i. Cholera red reaction
ii. Kanagawa phenomena
iii. Black colonies on Tinsdale media
iv. yellow colonies on TCBS agar
V. School of fish appearance on wet mount
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a string test,shown by Vibrio Cholerae. A suspension of the bacteria, along with bile salts gives a positive test. Along with this, Vibrio also shows a positive nitrate reduction test.

On a wet mount, it gives a FISH IN STREAM appearance. It is a non fastidious bacteria. Transport media include Autoclaved sea water and VR media. Enrichment media includes Alkaline peptone water and Monsurs taurocholate tellurite agar. Selective media are TCBS, where v.cholerae show yellow colonies and monsurs GTTA. they are late lactose fermenters.

Other options:

Kanagawa phenomena is shown by V. Parahaemolyticus Black colonies on Tinsdale media are shown by C. diphtheria

School of fish appearance is shown by H.Ducreyi, while V.cholera shows Fish in stream Appearance

Reference: Apurva shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no 414

questions.text: A 32 years female patient presented in gynaecology OPD for the first time in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. She had complaints of easy fatigue and increased craving for eating ice. She had no other complaints. On Examination her conjunctiva is pale. Clubbing of nails is seen and on auscultation grade-3 systolic murmur present. Which of the following laboratory parameters shows decreased value if the patient had above signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
The female is suffering from anemia of pregnancy. The most useful test with which to render a diagnosis of anemia is a low RBC count, however hemoglobin and hematocrit values are most commonly used in making the initial diagnosis of anemia.

Testing involved in diagnosing anemia in the pregnant person must be tailored to each individual patient. Suggested tests include: hemoglobin and hematocrit (ratio of red blood cells to the total blood volume), Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV), Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH), erythrocyte count (number of red blood cells in the blood), Redcell Distribution Width (RDW), Reticulocyte count, and a Peripheral Smear to assess red blood cell morphology. If iron deficiency is suspected, additional tests such as: serum iron, total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), transferrin saturation, and plasma or serum ferritin may be warranted. Serum ferritin is the best diagnostic parameter indicating poor iron stores. Iron stores have declined first marked by the decline is serum ferritin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 1021

questions.text:
You are performing the ZN staining for your microbiology practicals. You notice that the decolourizer is 5% sulphuric acid. Which of the following will stain acid fast positively with this concentration of sulphuric acid?
i. M.Leprae
ii. MAC
iii. Legionella
iv. M.tuberculosis
v. oocyst of cryptosporidium
vi. oocyst of tenia
vii. actinomyces
questions.solution:
The above question describes the modified ZN staining, wherein 5% sulphuric acid is used instead of 20%. The former concentration shows positive with M. Leprae, whereas the latter shows acid fastness for M.TB and Atypical mycobacteria.

Oocysts of cyclospora, isospora and cryptosporidium are also acid fast with 5% H2SO4 Nocardia, Legionella andTenia oocysts are acid fast with 0.5%-1% H2SO4. Actinomyces is not acid fast.

Reference: Apurva shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no 29

questions.text: Identify the type of hemorrhage shown in the image below
questions.solution:
An EDH is a collection of blood between the calvaria and outer (periosteal) layer of the dura. EDHs are biconvex in shape. Adherence of the periosteal dura to the inner calvaria explains this typical configuration. As EDHs expand, they strip the dura away from the inner table of the skull, forming the classic lens-shaped hematoma. Because the dura is especially tightly attached to sutures, EDHs in adults rarely cross suture lines (10% of EDHs in children do cross sutures, especially if a fracture traverses the suture or sutural diastasis is present).

Reference: Osborn's Brain: Imaging, Pathology, and Anatomy, Second edition, Page 21

questions.text: A 26 year old female is planned for an emergency caesarean section for preeclampsia. She is planned for general anaesthesia under rapid sequence induction. Which of the following is a Pre requisite for RSI?
questions.solution:
Preoxygenation: Administration of 100% O2 before induction of anaesthesia. Increases the O2 reserve in the lungs(by replacing N2 in the FRC) and thus the time to hypoxaemia during subsequent apnoea, e.g. during tracheal intubation. Also increases arterial PO2, although O2 content and saturation may not increase by much. Particularly useful when difficulties are anticipated or in patients at risk from aspiration of gastric contents. Thus a vital part of 'rapid sequence induction'.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no. 479.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a morbidity indicator?
questions.solution:
• Option B) Years of Potential life lost(YPLL) is a mortality indicator, not a morbidity indicators.
  • Notification rates, spells of sickness, incidence, prevalence, attendance rates at OPD, admission, discharge and readmission rates, duration of stay in hospital are morbidity indicators.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Prevention and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Pg: 26.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the AIIMS-OPD with his glomerular filtration rate is calculated to be 100 mL/min/1.73 m2 and glucose clearance is calculated to be 96 mL/min. Consultant asks you about the most likely agent the patient is on.
questions.solution:
This patient's glucose clearance is approaching the GFR, suggesting that almost none of the filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the kidney.

In healthy individuals, glucose is reabsorbed by SGLT-2 in the PCT and the glucose clearance is 0 mL/min. But in a diabetic patient with hyperglycemia, SGLT-2 becomes saturated and excess glucose is excreted in urine so that the glucose clearance is > 0 mL/min but less than the GFR. If SGLT-2 is inhibited(canagliflozin), none of the glucose is reabsorbed. Instead, glucose is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted. In this case, glucose clearance would approach the value of the GFR.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 758.

questions.text: Which one is the most reliable criteria for age estimation in Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
Root resorption: Root resorption starts first at the apex and extends upwards. It may depend on pathological conditions.

Cementum apposition: The cementum increases in thickness particularly due to change in the tooth position, especially near the end of the root.

Periodontosis: Regression of gums and periodontal tissues surrounding the teeth take place in advancing age. Poor oral hygiene increases periodontitis.

Transparency of root: With the age canals in the dentin filled by minerals, so that they become translucent gradually and the dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 391.

questions.text: A 84-year-old man with gram stain of CSF shows gram-positive rods resembling diphtheroids, the antibiotic regimen for empiric treatment would include
questions.solution:
Diphtheroid-like Gram-positive rods in the cerebrospinal fluid smear of an elderly patient are indicative of L-monocytogenes. Listeria infections are more common in neonates, elderly patients and those who have been treated with immunosuppressive agents. Cephalosporins do not cover listeria. (Mnemonic: "LAME": listeria, atypicals, MRSA and enterococcus.) Treatment consists of ampicillin with or without an amino glycoside such as gentamicin.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can also be used.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 802.

choices.text: Cell-cell contacts are lost by inactivation of E-cadherin
Some tumour show organ tropism due to expression of adhesion or chemokine receptors whose ligands are expressed by endothelial cells at the metastatic site
Sarcomas preferably metastasize through the lymphatic route
SNAIL and TWIST are metastasis oncogenes

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT TRUE for invasion and metastasis?
questions.solution:
Lymphatic spread is more typical of carcinomas, whereas hematogenous spread is favored by sarcomas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page number 196.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and prescribed a medication to prevent stroke. She develops a lesion, shown in the photograph taken fourth and six days after the drug is begun respectively. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Warfarin, a coumarin anticoagulant, inhibits epoxide reductase, which blocks the ability to activate vitamin K. This prevents the vitamin K-dependent gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VI, IX and X, thus inhibiting their synthesis. Warfarin similarly inhibits the vitamin - dependent synthesis of protein C and S, which have anticoagulant properties resulting from their inhibition of activated factors VIll and V.

Clopidogrel(A): Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent, not an anticoagulant. It is often used to prevent blood clots in conditions like atherosclerosis.

Enoxaparin(B): Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin and is an anticoagulant. It is often used for prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis(DVT) and pulmonary embolism.

Heparin(C): Heparin is an anticoagulant. It is used for various indications, including preventing and treating blood clots.

Warfarin(D): Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is often prescribed for patients with atrial fibrillation to prevent stroke.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 312.

questions.text: Heart failure cells are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In chronic pulmonary congestion, the septa become thickened and fibrotic, and the alveolar spaces contain numerous macrophages laden with hemosiderin("heart failure cells") derived from phagocytosed red cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page number 97.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is presented to the ED with severe tachycardia after a drug overdose. His family reports that he has been depressed. Past history of hypertension is present. Which one of the following drugs increases the heart rate in a dose-dependent manner?
questions.solution:
Given a clinical scenario of overdose of a drug in a hypertensive patient which causes tachycardia, points towards a class of anti-hypertensive which causes increased heart rate. Direct vasodilators(Option D) regularly increase heart rate(by reflex tachycardia) and minoxidil, a very efficacious vasodilator, causes severe tachycardia that must be controlled with β blockers.


Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 174-176.

choices.text: Plain radiographs of the right knee

questions.text: A 43-year-old male with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes is brought to the emergency room for fever and pain in the right knee. His temperature is 101.2°F, pulse is 113/min and blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. An examination of the right knee reveals limited range of motion, a moderate joint effusion and severe tenderness to palpation. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
This patient has multiple signs and symptoms of septic arthritis. The best next test to order is arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis and culture, since this is ideally performed prior to the initiation of antibiotics. Plain radiographs would likely also be obtained since, in rare cases, there may be concomitant osteomyelitis; however, these can be done after arthrocentesis so as not to delay appropriate treatment.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page number 822.

questions.text: An investigator studying viral replication isolates the genetic material of an unidentified virus strain. After exposing a cell culture to the isolated, purified viral genetic material, the cells begin to produce viral polymerase and subsequently replicate the viral genome. Infection with the investigated strain is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Poliovirus is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA ((+)ssRNA) virus.

The genetic material of (+)ssRNA viruses, which is essentially equivalent to eukaryotic mRNA, can be readily translated by the host cell into the proteins necessary for the viral life cycle, including viral polymerases.

Viral genetic fragments are infectious because an intact virion is not necessary for viral reproduction. All other (+)ssRNA viruses have this capability, including rhinovirus, coxsackieviruses, echovirus and hepatitis A virus.

Reference: Apurva Shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, Page no. 80.

questions.text: What is the investigation of the choice of a 5 year old patient presenting to the emergency department with an acute onset of RIF pain?
questions.solution:
The patient is presented with an acute abdomen. In acute abdomen the investigation of choice is CECT abdomen but in pediatric patients the IOC is USG. As CECT abdomen exposes the child to harmful radiation, USG is preferred. Also the child may not lie still in the scanning machine and need sedation which increases other risks. Thus in pediatric patients USG is the investigation of choice in acute abdomen.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology, 2nd edition, Page no. 2079.

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetic is used as a part of tumescent anesthesia
questions.solution:
The "tumescent" technique for liposuction is carried out via the subcutaneous infiltration of large volumes(5 o r more liters) of solution containing highly diluted lidocaine(0.05% to 0.10%) with epinephrine(1:100,000). The taut stretching of overlying blanched skin by the large volume of solution and epinephrine-induced vasoconstriction is the origin of the term tumescent technique. The result is sufficient local anesthesia for the liposuction, virtually bloodless aspirates and prolonged postoperative analgesia.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no. 307.

questions.text: Reactivated TB is located most commonly in which anatomical part of lung.
questions.solution:
Secondary pulmonary tuberculosis is classically localized to the apex of one or both upper lobes. The reason is obscure but may relate to high oxygen tension in the apices.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page number 529.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with Alzheimer's disease having complained of multiple episodes of Strong, sudden sense of urinary urgency with incontinence. Which of the following is the ideal agent for him for this condition?
questions.solution:
Here, in patients with Alzheimer with urge incontinence, a drug with quaternary ammonium structure is preferred as it doesn't cross BBB and doesn't exacerbate symptoms by blocking cholinergic neurons. In the given option, only trospium has quaternary structure.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 124.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most resistant to knife penetration?
questions.solution:
The tissue most resistant to knife penetration is the skin, apart from bone or calcified cartilage.

When a knife-point impacts against the skin, the latter dimples and resists. The tension developed in the stretched skin appears to act as an elastic reservoir and when the threshold of resistance is exceeded, penetration suddenly occurs.

Muscle offers little resistance to penetration. Uncalcified cartilage and subcutaneous tissue are easily penetrated by a sharp knife.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 156.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy admitted with failure to thrive with high glutamine and Uracil in urine Hypoglycemia, high blood ammonia. Treatment given for 2 months. At 8 months again admitted for failure to gain weight. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated, child became comatose. Parenteral Dextrose given. Child recovered from coma within 24 hours. What is the enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
In the given case is a deficiency of Ornithine transcarbamylase enzyme and for that clue to diagnosis are:

  • High glutamine: Usually seen in Because Ammonia is the transport form of ammonia from the brain and most other tissues. So in hyperammonemia, Glutamine level is elevated.
  • Increased uracil in urine can be seen in Ornithine Transcarbamoylase defect because as OTC defective, carbamoyl phosphate in mitochondria spills to cytoplasm. Then it enters into Pyrimidine synthesis. Pyrimidine intermediates and pyrimidines can accumulate. Hence, Uracil in urine.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page: 295.

questions.text: The serum electrophoresis was performed and the following pattern was obtained. The peak on the extreme left of the graph indicates
questions.solution:
The peak on the extreme left indicates the peak of albumin since it is present in maximum concentration in the plasma of the person. The extreme right peak indicates the gamma globulin fraction of the plasma that comes next in concentration to albumin.

Reference: Guyton's textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, Page number 112.

questions.text: A 11-year-old child is having learning difficulties at primary school. He has brief lapses of awareness with eyelid fluttering that occur every 10-20 min. Electroencephalogram(EEG) studies reveal brief 3-Hz spike and wave discharges appearing in all leads. Which drug would be not effective in this child?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario of child with learning difficulties and brief lapses of awareness with eyelid fluttering suggestive of Absence Seizure which can be confirmed by EEG showing typical 3-Hz spike and wave pattern.

Option A & B: First line drug for the treatment is Ethosuximide > Valproate.

Option C: However, Clonazepam can be used but exerts troublesome CNS-depressant effects and tolerance develops with chronic use.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Pg no. 423.

questions.text: Which of the following cells are positive for Non-Specific Esterase stain?
questions.solution:
Non-Specific Esterase(NSE) stain is a laboratory technique used to identify specific types of cells based on their enzyme activity. In the context of hematopoietic cell differentiation, monoblasts are positive for Non-Specific Esterase.

Myeloblasts (A): Myeloblasts are positive for Sudan Black B, but they are negative for Non-Specific Esterase.

Monoblasts (B): Monoblasts are positive for Non-Specific Esterase, which helps in differentiating them from other types of blasts.

Lymphoblasts (C): Lymphoblasts are typically negative for Non-Specific Esterase.

Megakaryoblasts (D): Megakaryoblasts are usually negative for Non-Specific Esterase.

Cytochemical profile in leukemia:

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page number 602.

questions.text: Equipment shown in the image is best sterilized by:
questions.solution:
• Equipment shown in the image is a Heart lung machine.
  • Heart lung machines, respirators and dental equipments are best sterilized by Ethylene oxide.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of microbiology, 10th edition, Pg: 130.

questions.text: Match the following to their respective category of thought disorders:
questions.solution:
• Disorders of stream of thought: Flight of ideas, Prolixity, Circumstantiality
  • Disorders of possession of thought: Obsessions and Compulsions, Thought alienation
  • Disorders of content of thought: Delusions
  • Thought alienation: Thought broadcasting, Thought withdrawal, Thought insertion
  • Other formal thought disorders: Derailment, Loosening of Association

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 662.

questions.text: The following antiarrhythmics are correctly matched to the Vaughan-Williams classification:
questions.solution:
The correct Vaughan-Williams classification:

Ia -Sodium channel blockade: Quinidine, procainamide

Ib -Sodium channel blockade: Lidocaine, phenytoin

Ic -Sodium channel blockade: Flecainide, propafenone

II - β-blockade: Propranolol, esmolol

III - Potassium channel blockade: Amiodarone, bretylium

IV - Calcium channel: blockade Verapamil, diltiazem

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no. 40.

questions.text: Which of the following antimuscarinic agents is approved to use in COPD?
questions.solution:
Ipratropium appears to be at least as effective in patients with COPD that includes a partially reversible component. A longer acting, selective antimuscarinic agent, tiotropium, is approved as a treatment for COPD.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page no. 347.

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.solution:
The image shows hinge fracture/motorcyclist fracture. Here, the base of the skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of the other like a hinge.

References: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 240.

questions.text: A 12 year old child presented with unsteadiness of gait. A photomicrograph of an HE stained slide of the biopsy from the posterior fossa is given below. Which of the following tumours is it likely to be:
questions.solution:
A pilocytic astrocytoma often is cystic, with a mural nodule in the wall of the cyst; if solid, it is usually well circumscribed.The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin 'hairlike' processes that are GFAP-positive. Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies, and microcysts are often present, while necrosis and mitoses are rare.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 883

questions.text: Hot-cold phenomenon is exhibited by which toxin?
questions.solution:
Beta hemolysin exhibits hot cold phenomenon. It is a sphingomyelinase that is hemolytic only for sheep cells and not human cells. It initiates hemolysis at 37 degree C but it is evident only after chilling. This is called the hot-cold phenomenon.

Reference:- Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of microbiology 10th edition pg 203

choices.text: Paranoid delusions regarding his family members

questions.text: An expert psychiatrist has been called upon to assess testamentary capacity for a 65- year-old male contemplating on making a written will of his properties. Which of the following symptoms if present in this testator can suggest testamentary incapacity?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of testamentary incapacity

  • Difficulties in attention and information processing
  • Language difficulties
  • Memory difficulties
  • Impairment of higher executive functions
  • Persecutory delusions
  • Delusions of poverty

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition - Page no 814

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female presents to OPD with C/O weakness, mild breathlessness on exertion and mild pedal oedema. Her peripheral blood smear is as shown below:

What is the most probable diagnosis on the above peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
As shown in the peripheral smears, M suggest Microcytosis (small size), H- Hypochromia (Less hemoglobin in red blood cells), P- poikilocytes (variation in shape) and T- target cells.

The red cells in the blood film are hypochromic and microcytic and there is anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. Hypochromia is generally due to poor filling of red cells with hemoglobin so there is increased central pallor. In severe cases, there may be a thin rim of pink staining at the periphery. Target cells, polychromatic cells and other elliptocytes may be present.

Normoblasts are uncommon. RBC count is below normal but is generally not proportionate to the fall of hemoglobin value. When iron deficiency is associated with severe folate or vitamin b12 deficiency, a dimorphic blood picture occurs with a dual population of red cells- microcytic and macrocytic hypochromic picture.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 299

choices.text: The structure to be demonstrated is stained
The structure to be demonstrated is not stained
The background and structure are stained

questions.text: True statement about negative staining is:
questions.solution:
Negative staining is a technique where the background is stained, and the structure to be demonstrated is not stained. This results in a dark background against which the unstained structure becomes visible. The contrast is achieved by staining everything except the structure of interest. It is particularly useful for visualizing certain types of structures, such as capsules around bacteria or the morphology of viruses.

Reference:- Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of microbiology 10th edition pg 1201

choices.text: Resistance to non depolarising muscle relaxant

questions.text: In a patient who is having a neuromuscular disease, myasthenia gravis, what is true in regards to muscle relaxants:
questions.solution:
• Myasthenia Autoimmune disease characterised by weakness and increased fatigability of skeletal muscle.
  • Caused by an immune response in which IgG autoantibodies are produced against the acetylcholine receptors of the neuromuscular junction postsynaptic membrane.
  • Peri-operatively: there is increased sensitivity to non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking drugs and relative resistance to suxamethonium with increased tendency to develop dual block.
  • Tracheal intubation and IPPV are usually performed without neuromuscular blocking drugs, using e.g. propofol and/or a volatile agent.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 392

choices.text: Mountain sickness, cause- high-altitude cerebral edema
Mountain sickness, cause- high-altitude pulmonary edema

questions.text: A 25 years old male patient went on a mountaineering expedition. Within 24hrs of ascent he developed headache, irritability, insomnia, breathlessness, nausea and vomiting. What is he suffering from and what is its cause?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive that the patient is suffering from Mountain Sickness. The low PO2 at high altitude causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral auto-regulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favours increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue. Individuals who do not develop mountain sickness have a diuresis at high altitude, and urine volume is decreased in individuals who develop the condition.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.649

choices.text: Persistent distal part of Vitellointestinal duct which usually disappears during Intrauterine life
2 inches long and 2 feet proximal to ileocecal valve
Vitellointestinal duct posses all three coats of intestinal wall

questions.text: Find a false statement about Meckel's diverticulum
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the persistent proximal part of the vitellointestinal duct which normally disappears during IUL life

Present in 2% subjects ; 2 inches (5 cm) long and is situated 2 feet (60 cm) proximal To ileocolic valve attached to antimesenteric border of ileum. Its calibre is equal to that of the ileum. Its apex may be free or attached to umblicus or mesentery by a fibrous band Vitellointestinal duct possesses all the layers of intestinal wall

Reference: B. D. Chaurasia's Textbook of Human anatomy Abdomen, fifth edition, Page 347

questions.text: Statin is a lipid lowering drug. Statin drug act by which of the following inhibition mechanisms on HMG CoA reductase?
questions.solution:
Acetoacetyl-CoA condenses with a further molecule of acetyl-CoA catalysed by HMG-CoA synthase to form HMG-CoA, which is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalysed by HMG-CoA reductase. This last step is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis and is the site of action of the most effective class of cholesterol- lowering drugs, the statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

The statin drugs that act as competitive inhibitors of HMGCoA reductase have Ki values several orders of magnitude lower than the Km for the substrate, HMG-CoA.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 267,82.

questions.text: When a nerve is cut, which of the following takes place first?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, myelin degeneration would be the best answer. However, the earliest change in Wallerian degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury (axonal degeneration) where there is disruption of the retrograde and ante retrograde flow of signals within the axon.

Reference: Guyton and hall 2nd Southeast Asia edition pg. 77 -Wallerian degeneration

questions.text: A 9 year old boy has developed prominent bruises on his extremities over the past week. On physical examination, he has ecchymosis and petechiae on his arms and legs. Laboratory studies show Hb- 13.8 g/l, PCV- 41%, MCV- 93 um3, platelet count - 22000 mm3 and WBC 7000mm3. He had respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia 3 weeks ago. His condition improves with corticosteroids. What can be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura and chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura are caused by antiplatelet antibodies but the acute one is typically seen in children after viral infection. If the marrow were aplastic, all cell lines should be reduced. Glycoprotein IIb-IIia deficiency is seen in Glanzman thrombocytopenia and chronic ITP. Scurvy owing to vitamin C deficiency leads to increased capillary fragility and ecchymosis but not to thrombocytopenia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 488

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents to the ED with a racing heartbeat. She is subsequently placed on continuous ECG monitor and irregular rhythm is seen. The diagnosis of atrial fibrillation is made. She is started on an amiodarone drip. What side effects should you be aware of when starting amiodarone?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone has several well-known side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, and thyroid imbalances. For this reason, pulmonary function tests, liver function tests, and thyroid function tests should be monitored while taking amiodarone.

  • Blurry yellow vision is a common side effect of digoxin toxicity, not However, blurry vision can be due to corneal micro-deposition of amiodarone.
  • Lupus-like syndrome is a common side effect of sulfonamide, hydralazine, isoniazid, procainamide (SHIP), which can be presented with malar rash, anti-histone antibody, which is reversible with drug discontinuation.
  • Prolongation of the AV refractory period is a common side effect of class Ic antiarrhythmics, such as flecainide and propafenone, not amiodarone.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Pg no. 243

questions.text: Which of the following general anaesthetic agents should not be used in patients with Acute intermittent porphyria?
questions.solution:
Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase, leading to the accumulation of porphyrin precursors. Some anaesthetic agents can potentially trigger acute attacks in patients with porphyria.

Propofol (A): Generally considered safe in patients with porphyria.

Pentothal (B): Thiopental (Pentothal) is associated with a higher risk of porphyria attacks and is contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria.

Etomidate (C): Generally considered safe in patients with porphyria. Ketamine (D): Generally considered safe in patients with porphyria.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition - Page no. 441

questions.text: Intestinal re-infection (Hyper infection syndrome) is seen in -
questions.solution:
Option B -in S.stercoralis infection, if patient has defective cellular response - AIDS patient, lepromatous leprosy, corticosteroid therapy or severe malnutrition, rhabditiform larva which are released in intestinal lumen instead of passing into faeces develop into filariform larva in intestine which penetrate intestinal mucosa and lodge into lungs and various tissue and organs - condition called as intestinal re-infection or Hyper infection syndrome.

Option A & D - intestinal re-infection usually does not occur in these parasites.

Option C - auto-infection and retro-infection is a feature of E. vermicularis in which eggs deposited in perianal skin, autoinfects person due to itching and unhygienic habits or larva hatched in perianal skin moves retrograde through anus causing retrograde autoinfection.

Reference :Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition - Page no 184

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is presented with acute onset of severe intermittent abdominal pain and nausea. He has had emesis when attempting to drink small amounts of fluids. The patient says that the severe abdominal pain began shortly after taking a new medication. On auscultation high pitched tinkling bowel sounds are heard. Which of the following drugs most likely precipitated the acute onset of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has bowel obstruction, as evidenced by the high-pitched "tinkling" bowel sounds, intermittent abdominal pain, obstipation (inability to pass flatus or stool), and abdominal distention.Afflicted patients may initially have episodic abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Fever and tachycardia may occur later if strangulation occurs.

Medications should be carefully considered for those with any degree of bowel obstruction because of the risk of worsening the obstruction or causing perforation of the intestinal tract.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition - Page no 1092

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following mechanism(s) lead to thrombosis?
i Endothelial Injury
ii Abnormal Blood Flow
iii Hyper Coagulation
iv Inflammation
questions.solution:
Endothelial Injury (i): Endothelial injury is a well-known factor that can contribute to thrombosis. When the inner lining of blood vessels (endothelium) is damaged, it exposes underlying tissues and triggers the activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.

Abnormal Blood Flow (ii): Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as turbulence or stasis, can lead to the formation of blood clots. Slow or stagnant blood flow increases the likelihood of platelet aggregation and clot formation.

Hypercoagulation (iii): Conditions associated with increased coagulation activity, such as certain genetic disorders or acquired conditions, can contribute to the formation of thrombi. This could involve an imbalance in procoagulant and anticoagulant factors in the blood.

Inflammation (iv): While inflammation is associated with many pathological processes, including atherosclerosis, it is not directly involved in thrombosis in the same way as endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulation. However, inflammation can indirectly contribute to thrombosis through its effects on the vessel wall and the coagulation system.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 107)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman falls in the bathroom and hurts her head. She regains her consciousness after a few minutes and continues with her daily activities. After 3 hours, she again becomes unconscious and collapses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes lucid interval and it is classically associated with extradural/ epidural haemorrhage (EDH).

Patients with EH present with 3 phases:

  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma.
  • The patient then awakens and has a lucid interval while the hematoma sub-clinically expands.
  • As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (CP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and unconscious.

A lucid interval is a period of normal consciousness and here the person is legally bound by the laws that affect normal people.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 184

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the lab which shows a serum potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L and a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows albuminuria. Lisinopril therapy is initiated. The next day, the patient returns due to lightheadedness and near-syncope. Her blood pressure is 102/66 mm Hg supine and 80/45 mm Hg standing. Her pulse is 94/ min. Which of the following is most likely the major factor contributing to this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with albuminuria was started on an ACE inhibitor for treatment of early diabetic nephropathy. Although most patients remain asymptomatic with only a mild reduction in blood pressure, first-dose hypotension can be a potential limiting factor when initiating ACE inhibitors. Significant hypotension is most likely to occur in patients with high plasma renin activity, such as those with volume depletion (eg, from diuretic use [hydrochlorothiazide in this patient]) or heart failure. Initiation of ACE inhibitor therapy causes abrupt removal of the vasoconstrictive effects of angiotensin I, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular tone and a precipitous drop in blood pressure in susceptible patients. To prevent the development of first- dose hypotension, therapy should be started at low doses and slowly titrated upward as needed.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Pg no. 192

questions.text: All are mechanisms seen with Type II hypersensitivity EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve the binding of antibodies (IgG or IgM) to antigens present on the surface of cells or tissues. The subsequent activation of the complement system and other effector mechanisms can lead to various outcomes.

  • Complement mediated lysis: This is a mechanism seen in Type II The complement system can cause lysis (destruction) of cells that have been targeted by antibodies.
  • Complement mediated inflammation: This is also a mechanism seen in Type II hypersensitivity. The activation of complement can lead to the recruitment of inflammatory cells and the induction of an inflammatory response.
  • Complex depositions in vessel wall: This is not typically associated with Type II hypersensitivity. Complex depositions in vessel walls are more characteristic of Type III hypersensitivity reactions, where immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.
  • Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction: This is a mechanism seen in Type II hypersensitivity. Antibodies can interfere with the normal function of cells, either by directly blocking receptors or by promoting the destruction of the targeted cells

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 135

questions.text: Penicillin resistance is transferred to Staphylococcus aureus by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Penicillin resistance in S. aureus is determined by plasmids that are mostly transferred by transduction.

The genetic transfer of antibiotic resistance occurs by following ways:

  • Transformation: after cell lysis some bacteria release their DNA fragments into the environment. Other bacteria generally of the same species come in contact with these free DNA fragments, take them and incorporate them in their own DNA by recombination.
  • Transduction: it involves transfer of DNA, episome or plasmid from one bacteria to another using bacteriophage.
  • Conjugation: it requires the presence of a special plasmid called F It is the most common method of transfer of antibiotic resistance in most bacteria.

Change in PBPs and production of B- lactamases are mechanisms of penicillin resistance in S.aureus.

Reference:- Apurva Shastri essentials of medical parasitology, 2nd edition, page no 206

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl came in an emergency with jaundice. Blood tests reveal uraemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood film demonstrates the presence of schistocytes. What is your probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a form of mechanical hemolytic anemia resulting from intravascular fragmentation and lysis of red cells due to microvascular endothelial abnormalities (like fibrin, platelet thrombi). Common causes are thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), eclampsia, hemolysis elevated enzymes low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome, disseminated malignancies and generalized vasculities. Blood film shows numerous fragmented red cells (schistocytes) and nucleated red cells.


Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia-peripheral blood smear.This specimen from a patient with hemolytic uremic syndrome contains several fragmented red cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 452

questions.text: A 6 years old male presented with severe anaemia and multiple joint pain. Identify the pathognomic abnormal red blood cells in the given peripheral smear of this patient.
questions.solution:
Hemoglobinopathies are a group of hereditary disorders caused by inherited mutations that lead to structural abnormalities in hemoglobin. Sickle cell anemia, the prototypic hemoglobinopathy, is caused by a mutation in β-globin that creates sickle hemoglobin (HbS).

Symptoms and complications may include: Anemia, pain crisis ,acute chest syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the following poisonous snakes.
questions.solution:

Russell's viper (b): Found in parts of Asia, including the Indian subcontinent, it is a highly venomous viper responsible for many snakebite incidents.

Saw-scaled viper (c): Found in parts of Africa, the Middle East, and the Indian subcontinent, it is a small but highly venomous snake.

King cobra (d): Found in South and Southeast Asia, it is the world's longest venomous snake and is known for its potent neurotoxic venom.

B. russel viper

questions.text: A 24-year-old female with candidiasis is given a one-time 100 mg dose of oral fluconazole. Administration of the medication results in a peak plasma concentration of 20 micro-g/mL. What is the apparent volume of drug distribution?
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution is calculated by dividing the total amount of drug in the body by the plasma concentration of the drug.

In this case, Vd = 100 mg fluconazole/20 micro-g/mL which is the peak plasma concentration. Thus, the volume of distribution of fluconazole is 5 L.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Pg no. 391

  • Organelle: By an extra mitochondrial system [in the cytosol] Cofactor requirements include

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a recent onset of weakness of her hands, diplopia, and difficulty swallowing. She has been treated for myasthenia gravis for several years. Which of the following is the best drug for distinguishing between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
Any of the cholinesterase inhibitors (choices B, C, or D) would effectively correct myasthenic crisis.

However, because a cholinergic crisis (if that is what is causing the symptoms) would be worsened by a cholinomimetic, we choose the shortest-acting cholinesterase inhibitor, edrophonium.

questions.text: Which of the followed labelled structures is responsible for keeping Actin and Myosin filaments in place?
questions.solution:
The labelled structure '3' is called Titin. Each titin molecule has a molecular weight of about 3 million, which makes it one of the largest protein molecules in the body. Also, because it is filamentous, it is very springy. These springy titin molecules act as a framework that holds the myosin and actin filaments in place so that the contractile machinery of the sarcomere will work. One end of the titin molecule is elastic and is attached to the Z disk, acting as a spring and changing length as the sarcomere contracts and relaxes. The other part of the titin molecule tethers it to the myosin thick filament.

Reference: Guyton's textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, page number 73

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes in with sneezing and clear nasal discharge. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past. He has benign prostatic hyperplasia and is on tamsulosin. Examination of the nasal cavity shows red, swollen turbinates. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This man has allergic rhinitis, which causes recurrent episodes of watery rhinorrhea and sneezing. Allergic rhinitis can be treated with H1 receptor antagonists. In this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia who thus has an increased risk of urinary retention, second- generation H1 receptor antagonists (e.g., desloratadine, fexofenadine, loratadine, cetirizine) are preferred because they have minimal anticholinergic effects compared to first-generation H1 receptor antagonists. Second-generation H1 receptor antagonists are also less sedating because they exist in an ionized state at physiologic pH and do not cross the blood-brain barrier.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Pg no. 283

questions.text: A 32 years old female patient presents with multiple small erythematous nodules on the face and right ear lobe. Skin biopsy from one such nodule shows presence of large aggregates of lipid-laden macrophages in dermis. Modified ZN stain (as shown in the figure below) shows plenty of acid-fast bacilli filled globi in macrophages. What is the microscopic diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Following features favours Lepromatous leprosy:

  1. In the dermis there is proliferation of macrophages with foamy They are called Virchow cells or lepra cells.
  2. The lepra cells are laden with acid fast bacilli demonstrated with AFB The AFB may be seen as compact globular masses (globi) or arranged in a parallel fashion like a cigarette pack.
  3. The dermal infiltration of lepra cells characteristically does not encroach upon the basal layer of epidermis and is separated from epidermis by a subepidermal uninvolved clear zone.
  4. The epidermis overlying the lesion is thinned out, flat and may be ulcerated.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 160

questions.text: Best disinfectant for the equipment shown in image is:
questions.solution:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding semen is incorrect:
1. bulk of the semen is formed by prostatic fluid.
2. semen contains profibrinolysin.
3. the sperms become motile within a few seconds once they are ejaculated.
4. average pH of semen is 6.8
5. fluid from the seminal vesicle gives the semen a mucoid consistency.
questions.solution:
The bulk of the semen is seminal vesicle fluid (hence statement 1 is incorrect), which is the last to be ejaculated and serves to wash the sperm through the ejaculatory duct and urethra. The average pH of the combined semen is about 7.5 (hence statement 4 is incorrect), the alkaline prostatic fluid having more than neutralized the mild acidity of the other portions of the semen. The prostatic fluid gives the semen a milky appearance, and fluid from the seminal vesicles and mucous glands gives the semen a mucoid consistency. In the early minutes after ejaculation, the sperm remain relatively immobile, possibly because of the viscosity of the coagulum. As the coagulum dissolves, the sperm simultaneously become highly motile (hence statement 3 is incorrect).

Reference: Guyton's textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, page number 976.

choices.text: Loss of sensitivity to green light

questions.text: The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is:
questions.solution:
In the retina, retinaldehyde (retinal) functions as the prosthetic group of the light-sensitive opsin proteins, forming rhodopsin (in rods) and iodopsin (in cones). Any one cone cell contains only one type of opsin and is sensitive to only one colour.

The absorption of light by rhodopsin causes isomerization of the retinaldehyde from 11-cis to all-trans, and a conformational change in opsin. This results in the release of retinaldehyde from the protein, and the initiation of a nerve impulse.

The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark. More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia (Bitot's spot), keratinization of the cornea, and blindness.

Option A:

Dark Adaptation Mechanism

Bright light depletes stores of rhodopsin in rods. So, when a person shifts suddenly from bright light to a dim light area, there is difficulty in seeing eg entering in cinema theatre

After a few minutes, rhodopsin is regenerated and vision is improved. This period is called dark adaptation time.

It is increased in vitamin A deficiency, due to less amount of rhodopsin.

Option C: Night blindness: Visual acuity is diminished in dim light. The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light. It occurs gradually after impairment to adapt in dim light.

Option D: Bitot's spot is Greyish white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva. This is due to dryness & increased thickness of conjunctival epithelium in certain areas. Seen during xerophthalmia, which occurs when prolonged vitamin A deficiency.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 530

questions.text: In an abrasion caused by tangential force, which of the following indicates the direction of said force?
questions.solution:
• In an abrasion caused by a tangential force, the direction of the force is determined by epidermal tags.
  • Abrasions caused by a tangential force are known as 'brush abrasion' or 'grazes' or 'brush ' It is commonly seen when a body is dragged over a rough surface, such as a road. This scrapes linear furrows across the skin. The epidermal tags raised by the impact tend to pile up at the distal end.

Option A: Fishtailing is the shape of the stab wound caused by a single-edged weapon. Option C: Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury in incised wounds.

Option D: Crushed hair follicles are seen at the edge of the wound in a laceration.

Reference: The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 136

questions.text:
Study the pictures below and answer.


i. Picture B is likely to be Follicular lymphoma because of variation in size of follicles which are present in the cortex and medulla and preservation of the mantle zone.
ii. Picture A is likely to be Follicular Hyperplasia because of absence of a mantle zone and uniform size of follicles
iii. Picture B is likely to be Follicular Hyperplasia because of the absence of a mantle zone and uniform size of follicles.
iv. Picture A is likely to be Follicular lymphoma because of variation in size of follicles which are present in the cortex and medulla and preservation of the mantle zone.
questions.solution:
In follicular lymphoma, Lymph nodes usually are effaced by a distinctly nodular proliferation. Most commonly, the predominant neoplastic cells are so-called 'centrocytes', cells slightly larger than resting lymphocytes that have angular 'cleaved' nuclei with prominent indentations and linear infoldings. The nuclear chromatin is coarse and condensed, and nucleoli are indistinct. These centrocytes are mixed with variable numbers of centroblasts, larger cells with vesicular chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm. In most tumors, centroblasts are a minor component of the overall cellularity, mitoses are infrequent, and single necrotic cells (cells undergoing apoptosis) are not seen. These features help to distinguish follicular lymphoma from follicular hyperplasia, in which mitoses and apoptosis are prominent. Uncommonly, large cells predominate, a histologic pattern that correlates with a more aggressive clinical behaviour.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 468

questions.text: A 35-year-old male comes to the clinic with severe pain in abdomen. The pain is localized in left flank region and radiates to the groin. Patient has no other complaints. After admitting the patient and providing pain management X-Ray is ordered. There is a visible calculus on the radio-imaging as marked in the picture. Which among the following statements is true regarding likely position of stone?
questions.solution:
Course of ureter: Arising from renal pelvis, ureter passes downwards and medially beneath the peritoneum of posterior abdominal wall, in front of psoas muscle and enters pelvic cavity by crossing the bifurcation of common iliac artery or beginning of external iliac artery. It passes downward along the margin of greater sciatic notch and reaches the level of ischial spine. It passes forward and medially above levator ani and reaches superolateral part of base of bladder and further pierces the musculature to open into the urinary bladder.

Posterior superior iliac spine cannot act as a landmark to locate ureter on Abdominal Xray (NOT B). Here, psoas muscle with its density gives a shadow visible on Xray which can help in locating the ureter. Any opacity visible in the course of psoas shadow can possibly be stone in ureter. The lower pole of the left kidney is opposite to the L3 plane, and this stone is likely in the sureter located in plane of L4.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy Vol-2 Lower Limb, Abdomen and Pelvis. 8th Edition. Pg 375

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient has been found to have gall stones also called as cholelithiasis. She has undergone the surgery for the same. Which of the following is not a function of gallbladder?

The bile is concentrated by 10 times and not by 20 times all other options are correct and normal functions of gall bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Essential fatty acid:
questions.solution:
Essential fatty acid

The fatty acids that are required by humans, but are not synthesised in the body hence need to be supplied in the diet are known as essential fatty acids (EFA). Humans lack the enzymes that can introduce double bonds beyond 9th Carbon.

They are polyunsaturated fatty acid namely

  • Linoleic Acid
  • Linolenic Acid
  • Linoleic acid is the most essential fatty acid
  • Arachidonic Acid is considered as Semi essential fatty Acid as it can be synthesised from Linoleic Acid.

Functions of essential fatty acid

  • They are integral components of membrane structure, often in the 2 positions of phospholipids
  • Eicosanoids are synthesised from Arachidonic Acid.
  • Essential fatty acids are needed for the synthesis of Arachidonic Acid
  • Lower the risk of Cardiovascular Diseases.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition - Page 242

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can lead to increased uric acid level in blood which is associated with reduced or absent uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Uric acid is an end product of purine nucleotide degradation. It is excreted by the kidney. The daily excretion of uric acid is around 600 mg.

Normal level of uric acid in blood is 3 to 7 mg/dl in male & 2-6 mg/dl in females (lower in female compared to male)

Gout is a metabolic disorder that occurs due to hyperuricemia. Due to low solubility of uric acid in water, it will get deposited in the synovial joint, leading to arthritis.

Hyperuricemia is an increased level of uric acid in blood (more than 7mg/dl).

It may or may not be associated with increased excretion of uric acid in urine (uricosuria). Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a condition that occurs almost exclusively in males. It is characterized by neurological and behavioral abnormalities and the overproduction of uric acid.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition - Page 334

questions.text: Which among the following is NOT a cardinal feature of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)?
questions.solution:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cause of cyanotic congenital heart disease. It accounts for about 5% of all congenital cardiac malformations. The four cardinal features are:

  • VSD
  • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (subpulmonic stenosis)
  • Overriding of the VSD by the aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Reference:Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, page number 406

It indicates some type of injuries to the cell

questions.text: Find the false statement about the pigment deposition shown in the image
questions.solution:
Lipofuscin is a yellow-brown, granular pigment that accumulates in cells during the ageing process. It does not indicate injury to the cell; rather, it is a product of the wear and tear of cellular components over time. The other statements about lipofuscin, including its perinuclear location, membrane-bound residual bodies, association with ageing (brown atrophy), and its presence in the heart in old age, are generally correct.

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of general sensations from anterior portion of his tongue while the rest of the general examination and facial examination was normal, the affected nerve arises from which pharyngeal arch :
questions.solution:
Loss of general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is a characteristic finding in lesions affecting the nerve derived from the first pharyngeal arch, which is the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve - CN V).

questions.text: Which of the following RNA is specifically used to decrease specific protein levels?
questions.solution:
The small non coding RNAs (ncRNAs) termed miRNAs (Micro-RNAs) and siRNAs (Silencing RNAs) typically inhibit gene expression at the level of specific protein production by targeting

mRNAs through one of several distinct mechanisms. siRNAs are frequently used to decrease or 'knockdown' specific protein levels (via siRNA homology-directed mRNA degradation) in experimental contexts in the laboratory.

questions.text: You are doing a presentation on Vibrio. You come across a species of vibrio which shows 'Kanagawa' phenomena and grows in a halophilic media of upto 8% salt solution. Which of the following vibrio species are you most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
V. Parahemolyticus shows the kanagawa phenomenon on wagatsuma agar. It grows in upto 8% salt solution, shows swarming growth on blood agar. It is known to cause invasive diarrhoea.

choices.text: 3' end has phosphorylated hydroxyl group
5' end has free hydroxyl group
Written by convention with the 5' end on right and 3' end on left

questions.text: All polynucleotides are directional macromolecules. Which of the following statements is true regarding direction in the polynucleotides chain?
questions.solution:
Option A and B: Polynucleotides Are Directional Macromolecules. Directional 3' → 5' phosphodiester bonds link the monomers of polynucleotides.

Since each end of a polynucleotide thus is distinct, we refer to the '5′-end' or the '3′-end' of a polynucleotide. Since the phosphodiester bonds are all 3' → 5', the representation pGpGpApTpCpA indicates that only the 5'-hydroxyl is phosphorylated and the 3' end has free hydroxyl group.

Option C: More concisely, the representation GGATC, which shows only the base sequence, is by convention written with the 5′-base (G) at the left and the 3′-base (C) at the right.

Option D: All phosphodiester bonds are 3' → 5'. It joins the 3' hydroxyl group of deoxyribose of one nucleotide to the 5' hydroxyl group of another nucleotide through the phosphate group.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition - Page 325

questions.text: A patient presented with breathing difficulties and hematuria, the resident ordered an immunofluorescence test and observed the following, which disease was he suspecting?
questions.solution:
The resident suspected Goodpasture syndrome. Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the lungs and kidneys. It is characterized by the presence of antibodies directed against the basement membrane of the lungs and kidneys.

In this case, the patient presented with breathing difficulties (indicating potential lung involvement) and hematuria (blood in the urine, suggesting kidney involvement). The immunofluorescence test was likely performed to detect the presence of antibodies against the basement membrane.

The characteristic finding in Goodpasture syndrome is the linear deposition of immunoglobulin G (IgG) along the basement membrane of the lungs and kidneys, which can be visualized through immunofluorescence microscopy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, page number 453

questions.text: Facial nerve has all the following neural columns EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Functional Components of Facial nerve

  • Special visceral or branchial efferent (SVE), responsible for muscles of facial expression and for elevation of the hyoid bone.
  • General visceral efferent (GVE) or parasympathetic fibres. These fibres are secretomotor to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, the lacrimal gland,glands of the nose, palate and pharynx.
  • General Somatic afferent (GSA) component carries afferent impulses from the above mentioned glands.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 8th Edition, Page No - 78
